Comments_List:
More pedagogical materials would be great. Maybe break vocabulary into themes (start with body parts, colors, numbers, etc since we have that) and introduce some new verb roots. Learn regularities of verb conjugation through repetition, homework could be more focused on this (choose the right preposition/verb conjugation) at first, building up to broader translation. These materials take effort to create, but maybe a class could collaborate to do this, the students creating the materials will gain experience this way and future classes will benefit from the materials.

The language game(s) were great, I think it could even start off with something like the card game earlier, since it drills much of the same vocab as the normal game. More skits or small conversations could be worked into the game days as well, to prevent burn out and keep us on task.

Overall very interesting class, I always found myself looking forward to the next meeting, which I can't really say for all courses.

I think a lot of people were looking for more structure, like there usually is in a big language class. Some of that can't be done without all the language resources that a big language has, but I think more structured lessons would've been helpful.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It provides a nice language learning environment and insight into a very interesting language. For linguists, especially those interested in phonology and morphology (and possibly syntax-semantics), there appears to be a lot of potential for research questions.
Yes, I think courses like this are really important and I think everyone enjoyed it and got something out of it.
